resources.string: When enabled, will use a random email or number as the target
Use random computer generated text for each SMS sent by this app
Enter the target recipient of the messages sent by this app
Chose the content of the messages sent by this app
You had better hope you have a warrant/wiretap to collect and store these messages. Also sure would be a shame if your stingray crashed from all these messages
Sets the delay between each message sent

Since the primary function of this application is to send SMS messages, it is rendered useless without the permission to send SMS messages. The contents of the messages that are sent through this app are never logged, saved or recorded by this app, nor are the destinations of the messages.If you do not wish to grant the permission to send SMS messages, this app will close and should be uninstalled.
The target address of the SMS messages
The contents of the next SMS message to be sent
Number of messages that have been actually sent
The number of SMS messages that produced delivery reports
If enabled, this allows you to configure the source value of the SMS messages sent. This may result in failure to send with some carriers
The label for the amount of time the service has been running for
Deletes all unsent messages in the outbox. May help if messages are failing to send.
If enabled, will write phone state variables to a log file for later analysis
"RayDos is currently running in the background. Click info to re-open the app or press exit to stop RayDos."
RayDos is currently running in the background

\"A Stingray is a device that pretends to be a cell phone tower. When it is turned on, it sends out a ping to all cellular devices within the reach of its signal and informs the devices that the Stingray is now online. \"
It informs the devices they should disconnect from the tower they are currently connected to, and register with the Stingray.
Stingrays are commonly referred to as IMSI Catchers, Dirtboxes, Kingfish, HailStorm, Stingray I, Stingray II, Gossamer, Triggerfish Cell Tower Simulators, and Cell Site Simulators.
Stingrays are mostly manufactured by the Florida company Harris Corporation.

Stingrays can intercept and forward the data and communications from all cellular devices that are within the area of range of the Stingray\'s antennae. Unencrypted data like text messages and phone calls are particularly vulnerable.
Stingrays can be used to block all incoming and outgoing information from reaching cell phones in the area of effect of the Stingray.

Theoretically, a Stingray could be used to invoke a cellphone\'s built-in over-the-air update mechanism, forcing the phone to install a malicious software update or to download a malicious app without the knowledge or authorization of the user.
With the help of a device called an AmberJack, Stingrays can be used to triangulate the exact location of target cell phones, including phones that do not have location services enabled.
Stingrays were originally developed for use by the U.S. Navy, but since then have been de-regulated by the FCC so that anybody with an antenna can create and operate a Stingray
Predominately, these devices are purchased and used by the U.S. Federal government, as well as State and local police and sheriff departments.
Among the list of federal agencies known to own and operate Stingrays, is the FBI, DEA, ICE, the Dept. of Justice, and the U.S. Marshals Service.

While running, RayDos will send out text messages with pre-defined content or with randomized content, in an attempt to overwhelm the StingRay and to make it harder for watching parties to discern real texts from ones generated by RayDos.
